title: Photos show thousands of people gathered in Odessa, Texas for an emotional tribute to the victims of Saturday's mass shooting
text:
Thousands of people in West Texas paid tribute on Sunday to the victims of a mass shooting which killed 7 people and left 22 injured.

The shooting occurred on Saturday afternoon after a gunman, named by police as 36-year-old Seth Ator, opened fire on authorities during a traffic stop.

He then fired at random as he drove to through Odessa and the nearby city of Midland, both located about 300 miles west of Dallas.

At one point, he hijacked a mail carrier truck and shot residents and law enforcement in Odessa, leading them on a 10-mile chase.

Police caught up with him near a movie theatre in Odessa, and killed him in a shootout. The shooting left seven people dead and 21 people injured. Police have not released a motive and have not said where the shooter purchased his weapon.

Saturday's events came just weeks after two mass shootings in El Paso, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio left a combined 31 people dead. 53 people have died in mass shootings in August alone, according to the New York Times.

On Sunday, over 2,000 people gathered to pay tribute to the victims of the latest mass shooting, according to University of Texas of the Permian Basin. Mourners at the university bowed their heads and lowered flags to half-mast.

Midland Mayor Jerry Morales told Associated Press that he did not understand how something like this could happen in his small town.

"We're out here in the middle of nowhere ... All we've talked about is oil forever. And then this happens."

Scroll down to see photos of how locals came together to mourn Saturday's loss of life.
description: The shooting, which killed 7 people and left 22 injured, was the third mass shooting to happen in the US in the month of August.
